item.title: Introduction
item.description: If you are completely new to LaTeX, I strongly recommend first looking at the LaTeX Basic Course. Many fundamental concepts will be used in this course, but not explained again.

item.title: Math Environments I
item.description: As usual, the math side of LaTeX has two major parts: environments and commands. The environments tell LaTeX: “hey, we want to go into math mode now” They also define some crucial overall functionality and layout to use in that mode.

item.title: Math Environments II
item.description: Last chapter discussed, among others, the displaymath and equation environment. Anywhere within these, you can use the sub environments I’ll discuss in this chapter.

item.title: Display Styles & Scripts
item.description: Earlier we saw two types of math environments: in line with the text (inline), or on its own line(s) (block).

item.title: Delimiters
item.description: Many mathematical formulas group their components with so-called delimiters. Think of regular arithmetic where 2*(5+6) is something different than (2*5)+6.

item.title: Math Accents
item.description: You can’t blindly use text within a math environment like you normally would. This has been discussed numerous times now.

item.title: Functions
item.description: Any characters put into a math environment are displayed in an italic math font. Some operators though, mostly functions, are typically written with other letter styles.

item.title: Sums, Integrals & More
item.description: Some mathematical “functions” are so important (or just weird-looking) that tehy have their own special symbols and operators! These aren’t written by simply using their (shortened) name.

item.title: Matrices
item.description: Using the delimiters seen before, you can already create matrices. Or, rather, things that look somewhat like a matrix.

item.title: Math Spacing & Special Text
item.description: Before I throw all existing symbols at you, some slight important details warrant mentioning. Within math environments, you can use the same spacing commands as anywhere else in LaTeX.

item.title: Greek Symbols
item.description: Within mathematics, it’s common to use Greek letters for naming nearly everything. It’s useful, because they are easily recognizable, but don’t interfere with regular text.

item.title: Math Symbols
item.description: I’ve already subtly mentioned that LaTeX uses a very complex set of rules to determine the amount of spacing around symbols.

item.title: Theorems & Proofs
item.description: Until now we’ve done everything inside math environments—which isn’t weird for a LaTeX Math course—but now it’s time to step out of it.

item.title: Math Graphics
item.description: In the basic course we saw the command for including a picture file. It was \includegraphics. Which is slightly odd, isn’t it?

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Hopefully you now have the tools to typeset any (complicated) mathematics, formulas, algorithms and theorems you want. Of course, there is way more available.
